distribution-help-entry.name: dnACLN
distribution-help-entry.title: The autocorrelated, lognormally distributed relaxed-clock model

description.p: This is the constructor function for the autocorrelated, log-normally distributed node rates on a tree. This model was described in Thorne et al. (1998), Kishino et al. (2001), and Thorne & Kishino (2002).

constructor-help-entry.usage: dnACLN( TimeTree tree, RealPos sigma, Real rootRate, RealPos scaleValue )

argument.label: tree
argument.description: The time-tree on which the node rates are mapped.

argument.label: sigma
argument.description: The variance parameter controlling the degree of autocorrelation among node rates.

argument.label: rootRate
argument.description: The rate value at the root.

details.p: This distribution gives a vector of RealPos values that are mapped to the non-root nodes of a tree. A separate function (aveRateOnBranch) taking this vector and the other ACLN parameters is used to compute the branch-rates.

constructor-help-entry.example:
## read in the tree T <- readTrees("data/bears_dosReis.tre")[1]
### Load the sequence alignment D <- readDiscreteCharacterData(file="data/bears_irbp.nex")
### get helpful variables from the data n_sites <- D.nchar(1) n_taxa <- D.ntaxa() n_branches <- 2 * n_taxa - 2 names <- D.names()
### initialize an iterator for the moves vector mi = 1
### Specify Yule (pure birth) tree prior birth_rate <- 0.1 root_time ~ dnExponential(0.1, offset=35.0) timetree ~ dnBDP(lambda=birth_rate, mu=0.0, rho=1.0, rootAge=root_time, samplingStrategy="uniform", condition="nTaxa", nTaxa=n_taxa, names=names)
### set up the base-rate parameter of the ACLN model base_rate <- 0.01
### set up the variance parameter of the ACLN model nu <- 0.1
### the clock rate at the root of the tree root_rate ~ dnGamma(2.0, 4.0)
### a vector of the rates at each node ### from the ACLN model, which is conditioned on the tree, nu, the root rate, and base rate node_rates ~ dnACLN(timetree, nu, root_rate, base_rate)
### the rate at each branch is the average of the rate at each node separated by that branch ### a special core function is used to calculate the rate for branch i for(i in 1:n_branches){ branch_rates[i] := aveRateOnBranch(node_rates, timetree, root_rate, base_rate, index=i) }
